com.samskivert.util
Class RunAnywhere

java.lang.Object
  com.samskivert.util.RunAnywhere

public class RunAnywhere
extends Object

Write once, run anywhere. Well, at least that's what it said in the brochures. For those less than fresh days, you might need to use this class to work around bugs on particular operating systems.

Constructor Summary
RunAnywhere()
           
 
Method Summary
static long currentTimeMillis()
          Returns System.currentTimeMillis(), but works around a bug on WinXP that causes time to sometimes leap into the past.
static long getWhen(InputEvent event)
          Returns the timestamp associated with the supplied event except on the Macintosh where it returns System.currentTimeMillis() because InputEvent.getWhen() returns completely incorrect values.
static boolean isLinux()
          Returns true if we're running in a JVM that identifies its operating system as Linux.
static boolean isMacOS()
          Returns true if we're running in a JVM that identifies its operating system as MacOS.
static boolean isWindows()
          Returns true if we're running in a JVM that identifies its operating system as Windows.

equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

isLinux

public static final boolean isLinux()
Returns true if we're running in a JVM that identifies its operating system as Linux.

currentTimeMillis

public static final long currentTimeMillis()
Returns System.currentTimeMillis(), but works around a bug on WinXP that causes time to sometimes leap into the past.

getWhen

public static long getWhen(InputEvent event)
Returns the timestamp associated with the supplied event except on the Macintosh where it returns System.currentTimeMillis() because InputEvent.getWhen() returns completely incorrect values. Hopefully this method will become unnecessary soon. We also no longer trust windows, since it seems to misbehave sometimes.
